105 C.M.R. 410.190.proposition: The Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, requires every dwelling unit to be supplied with hot water in sufficient quantity and at adequate temperature.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment” of a tenant’s premises is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), every residential lease includes a covenant that the tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the rented premises during the term of the tenancy.

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment recognized under Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), every residential lease includes a covenant that the tenant shall have quiet enjoyment of the rented premises during the term of the tenancy.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: The provided text is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability and code-based duties, not on G.L. c. 186, § 14 or quiet enjoyment. However, the majority opinion in Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway is well-known in Massachusetts law for recognizing that every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, grounded in § 14 and common law. Because the proposition accurately states the rule for which Hemingway is authoritative, but the quoted portion does not itself articulate it, the case overall supports the proposition, though not in the excerpt provided.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that '[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair...' ... The opinion of the court in the present cases does not discuss or otherwise deal with the rule quoted above from Palmigiani v. D’Argento... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule...

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The deprivation of essential services, including hot water, may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff involves excessive noise from a lounge constituting a constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where the landlord had the ability to control the nuisance. The opinion does mention, by citation to another case, that failure to supply heat, light, power and elevator services can breach quiet enjoyment, but Blackett itself does not address deprivation of essential services like hot water. It therefore does not directly support the specific proposition that deprivation of essential services, including hot water, may constitute such a breach; that principle is grounded more squarely in the cited Burt and later Simon v. Solomon cases.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The deprivation of essential services, including hot water, may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns deprivation of essential services like hot water as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Simon v. Solomon involves flooding and unsanitary conditions, not deprivation of utilities or hot water, and the quiet enjoyment discussion focuses on interference from repeated flooding. While the case interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment broadly, it does not address hot water or other essential services, so it does not directly support that specific proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy…. When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” (385 Mass. at 100–102)

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain hot water service for over three weeks, despite notice and opportunity to cure, constitutes a “serious interference” with Plaintiff’s tenancy and thus a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See also Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable measures to address serious drug activity in common areas can constitute a “serious interference” with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. However, the opinion does not involve or mention any failure to maintain hot water service, nor does it discuss lack of hot water as a form of serious interference. Using this case as authority for the specific proposition about three weeks without hot water misstates its holding and extends it to facts it never addressed.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322.raw_text: Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322 Mass. 556 (1948)
Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322.proposition: Violation of the Sanitary Code supports a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment. See Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322 Mass. 556 (1948).
Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians does not address landlord-tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, or the Sanitary Code at all. It is a will-construction case concerning when charitable legacies become payable and whether a trust lapsed; there is no discussion of housing conditions or code violations. Therefore, it cannot provide authority for the proposition that violation of the Sanitary Code supports a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
Lipsitz v. State Bd. of Sanitarians, 322.relevant_excerpt: "This is a petition for the interpretation of the will of Susan Helen Fuller... It is the contention of the petitioner that, on the death of the testatrix, the bequest in trust to Nash did not lapse but survived as a 'dry or passive trust'... The respondent executors contend that the bequest in trust to Nash lapsed... The decree of the Probate Court is affirmed."

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The landlord’s duty to repair and maintain essential facilities, including hot water systems, is nondelegable. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlord’s warranty-of-habitability obligation to provide heat and hot water is effectively strict (fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not matter for rent abatement), but it frames this as a matter of contract/warranty and statutory Code duties, not as a ‘nondelegable’ duty in the tort or vicarious-liability sense. The court discusses that these Sanitary Code duties cannot be waived or bargained away, yet it never characterizes the duty as nondelegable or addresses delegation to contractors or agents. Thus it is supportive of strict, non-waivable responsibility for habitability, but does not clearly establish the specific proposition that the duty to repair and maintain essential facilities is “nondelegable.”
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 199. Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice. The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff’s inability to use essential plumbing and bathing facilities constitutes a deprivation of a “materially habitable environment.” Hemingway, supra; Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion as excerpted does not discuss lack of plumbing, bathing facilities, or the concept of a “materially habitable environment.” The habitability discussion is limited to general sanitary code violations and rent abatement, without characterizing any loss of essential plumbing or bathing facilities as rendering the premises materially uninhabitable. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the "percentage reduction approach in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation. See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was at least negligent, and his failure to promptly restore essential services constitutes a per se breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that liability does not depend on intent, but on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct. The court rejects financial inability as a defense and orders injunctive relief and damages once heat was not provided, effectively treating the failure to furnish this essential service as at least negligent and as a per se violation of quiet enjoyment. This directly supports using the case for the stated proposition about non‑restoration of essential services breaching quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to…a declaration that the landlords had violated G.L. c. 186, § 14….”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s conduct was at least negligent, and his failure to promptly restore essential services constitutes a per se breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. See Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does support the first half of the proposition: it expressly holds that at least negligent conduct (some degree of fault/foreseeability) is required for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, it does not address, much less establish, any rule that a landlord’s failure to promptly restore essential services is a per se breach of quiet enjoyment; that subject is not discussed in this case. Thus, Al‑Ziab is being cited too broadly for the ‘per se’ essential-services component of the proposition.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”
